qas.question: What became tourist destinations during the 19th century?

answers.text: the monasteries built in the high Alps

qas.question: Who built monasteries in Lucerne, Switzerland and Oberammergau?
Who had abbeys in the Savor and one in the center of Interlaken?
When was the Great St. Bernard Hospice built?

context: In the 19th century, <a0_0>the monasteries built in the high Alps<a0_0/> during the medieval period to shelter travelers and as places of pilgrimage, became tourist destinations. <a1_0>The Benedictines<a1_0/> had built monasteries in Lucerne, Switzerland, and Oberammergau; the Cistercians in the Tyrol and at Lake Constance; and <a2_0>the Augustinians<a2_0/> had abbeys in the Savoy and one in the center of Interlaken, Switzerland. The Great St Bernard Hospice, built in <a3_0>the 9th or 10th centuries<a3_0/>, at the summit of the Great Saint Bernard Pass was shelter for travelers and place for pilgrims since its inception; by the 19th century it became a tourist attraction with notable visitors such as author Charles Dickens and mountaineer Edward Whymper.
